The 'Sahara' (, {{transl|ar|DIN|aá¹£-á¹¢aá¸¥rÄÊ¾ al-KubrÄ }}, 'the Greatest
Desert') is the world's hottest desert, and the third largest desert after
Antarctica and the Arctic. At over , it
covers most of North Africa, making it almost as large as China or the United
States. The Sahara stretches from the Red Sea, including parts of the
Mediterranean coasts, to the outskirts of the Atlantic Ocean. To the south, it
is delimited by the Sahel, a belt of semi-arid tropical savanna that composes
the northern region of central and western Sub-Saharan Africa.

Some of the sand dunes can reach in height. Arthur N. Strahler and Alan H.
Strahler. (1987) Modern Physical Geography Third Edition. New York: John Wiley &
Sons. Page 347 The name comes from the plural Arabic language word for
desert ( {{transl|ar|á¹£aá¸¥ÄrÄ }} [http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?-
